cards.title: House collapses into river during floods in southern Chile
cards.rawTitle: House collapses into river during floods in southern Chile

item.title: House collapses into river during floods in southern Chile
item.trailText: Amateur video captures the moment a home in Chile is swept away in floodwaters from the overflowing Queche river
item.standFirst: Amateur video captures the moment a home in Chile is swept away by floodwaters from the overflowing Queche river. A torrential rain storm had dumped more than 100 ml (nearly 4 inches) of rain on the country's southern Los Lagos region in just 24 hours. 'All of a sudden, the house disappeared,' said its owner

stillImage.caption: A house collapses into a river in Chile during floods. 20 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
stillImage.cleanCaption: A house collapses into a river in Chile during floods. 20 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

displayImages.caption: A house collapses into a river in Chile during floods. 20 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.altText: house collapse
displayImages.cleanCaption: A house collapses into a river in Chile during floods. 20 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: Breakfast at Audrey's / Hepburn family photo album unlocked

item.title: Breakfast at Audrey's: the Hepburn family photo album unlocked
item.trailText: See an ordinary girl become a star, from her days picking flowers and doing dance recitals to screen tests for Sabrina and the cover of LIFE magazine. Hepburn’s sons have opened up their family vaults to show the world an icon in an intimate new light
item.standFirst:
See an ordinary girl become a star, from her days picking flowers and doing dance recitals to screen tests for Sabrina and the cover of LIFE magazine. Hepburn’s sons have opened up their family vaults to show the world an icon in an intimate new light

• Audrey Hepburn: Portraits of an Icon will be at the National Portrait Gallery from 2 July-18 October

cards.title: Meet the winners / Asian women of achievement awards

item.title: Asian women of achievement awards 2015: meet the winners
item.trailText: Founded in 1999, the awards ‘celebrate the often unsung Asian heroines of British life’. We share some words of wisdom from this year’s inspiring winners
item.standFirst: Founded in 1999, the awards ‘celebrate the often unsung Asian heroines of British life’. We share some words of wisdom from this year’s inspiring winners

displayImages.caption:
Business award - Sevasti Wong, managing director at Accenture

“There have always been outstanding Asian women in UK business but it was rare in the past to see an Asian businesswoman featured in the media. This is slowly changing and Asian women are starting to be more visible and vocal.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Sevasi Wong
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Business award - Sevasti Wong, managing director at Accenture

“There have always been outstanding Asian women in UK business but it was rare in the past to see an Asian businesswoman featured in the media. This is slowly changing and Asian women are starting to be more visible and vocal.”

displayImages.caption:
RBS AWA chairman’s award - Jyoti Shah, consultant urological surgeon at Burton Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

“There are many positive depictions of modern Asian women in British society today – they are making great strides and helping to change the negative stereotypes. The young Asian girl has many role models to shadow and she too one day will become tomorrow’s role model for the next generation by emulating her heroines today.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Jyoti Shah
displayImages.cleanCaption:
RBS AWA chairman’s award - Jyoti Shah, consultant urological surgeon at Burton Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

“There are many positive depictions of modern Asian women in British society today – they are making great strides and helping to change the negative stereotypes. The young Asian girl has many role models to shadow and she too one day will become tomorrow’s role model for the next generation by emulating her heroines today.”

displayImages.caption:
Arts and culture award - Sajeela Kershi, comedian, actor and writer

“Believe in yourself even if no one else does, go with your gut, do what you want and do it your way. Don’t listen to anyone who tells you it’s too late: it’s never too late to make your dreams come true, but you need to focus and work damn hard.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Sajeela Kershi
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Arts and culture award - Sajeela Kershi, comedian, actor and writer

“Believe in yourself even if no one else does, go with your gut, do what you want and do it your way. Don’t listen to anyone who tells you it’s too late: it’s never too late to make your dreams come true, but you need to focus and work damn hard.”

displayImages.caption:
Media award - Shivvy Jervis, presenter at Digital Futures and head of digital media at Telefónica

“For millennial Asian women, the work sphere isn’t now limited to one’s ‘day job’. I’ve been able to build my personal brand within the wider industry precisely because I have proactively invested time and effort across both my day-to-day commitments and the ones outside.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Shivvy Jervis
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Media award - Shivvy Jervis, presenter at Digital Futures and head of digital media at Telefónica

“For millennial Asian women, the work sphere isn’t now limited to one’s ‘day job’. I’ve been able to build my personal brand within the wider industry precisely because I have proactively invested time and effort across both my day-to-day commitments and the ones outside.”

displayImages.caption:
Professions award - Nicky Jayesinghe, head of professional policy division at the British Medical Association

“One of my proudest achievements has been to champion the under-representation of women in the BMA. Since 2013 I have designed and implemented a number of initiatives to encourage diversity, including a mentoring scheme, visitors’ scheme and core leadership training.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Nicky Jayesinghe
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Professions award - Nicky Jayesinghe, head of professional policy division at the British Medical Association

“One of my proudest achievements has been to champion the under-representation of women in the BMA. Since 2013 I have designed and implemented a number of initiatives to encourage diversity, including a mentoring scheme, visitors’ scheme and core leadership training.”

displayImages.caption:
Public service award - Daman Mullhi, director of PR at the UK Sepsis Trust

“Any prejudice you may face is a small part of your journey and these ‘differences’ will make your journey unique and more colourful. Be strong, trust yourself and enjoy. There is something positive in almost everything.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Daman Mullhi
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Public service award - Daman Mullhi, director of PR at the UK Sepsis Trust

“Any prejudice you may face is a small part of your journey and these ‘differences’ will make your journey unique and more colourful. Be strong, trust yourself and enjoy. There is something positive in almost everything.”

displayImages.caption:
Global empowerment award - Elif Shafak

“Asia is changing and women are at the forefront of this transformation. Together with the rise of urbanisation and the spread of education, the average age of marriage has increased. However, the culture and the society are not there yet. Society still puts pressure on women to conform to traditional gender roles. So while social norms are changing way too slowly, women have been changing faster. This gap is something we need to deal with in the next decade.”

 Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Efli Shakak
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Global empowerment award - Elif Shafak

“Asia is changing and women are at the forefront of this transformation. Together with the rise of urbanisation and the spread of education, the average age of marriage has increased. However, the culture and the society are not there yet. Society still puts pressure on women to conform to traditional gender roles. So while social norms are changing way too slowly, women have been changing faster. This gap is something we need to deal with in the next decade.”

displayImages.caption:
Entrepreneur award - Farzana Baduel, founder of Curzon PR

“The fact that I took the risk to start my company during such a turbulent time, and have been able to grow it into the successful international agency it is today, is something that I am incredibly proud of.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Farzana Baduel
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Entrepreneur award - Farzana Baduel, founder of Curzon PR

“The fact that I took the risk to start my company during such a turbulent time, and have been able to grow it into the successful international agency it is today, is something that I am incredibly proud of.”

displayImages.caption:
Sport award - Annie Zaidi, youth engagement coach at Leicester City Football Club Community Trust

“I think the working world has inspired Asian women to break down social perception of them and allowed them to work hard and realise their full potential as business women across all sectors of the working world. These trailblazer have and are continuing to empower other Asian women like myself to follow our dreams of becoming successful in our chosen field.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Annie Zaidi
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Sport award - Annie Zaidi, youth engagement coach at Leicester City Football Club Community Trust

“I think the working world has inspired Asian women to break down social perception of them and allowed them to work hard and realise their full potential as business women across all sectors of the working world. These trailblazer have and are continuing to empower other Asian women like myself to follow our dreams of becoming successful in our chosen field.”

displayImages.caption:
Social and Humanitarian award - Parmi Dheensa, executive director at Include Me TOO

“I believe in equality, inclusion and disability rights and feel very fortunate for having the opportunity to make a real difference and share the journeys of many disabled children and families through my charity Include Me TOO (inspired by my youngest son Callum).” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Parmi Dheensa
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Social and Humanitarian award - Parmi Dheensa, executive director at Include Me TOO

“I believe in equality, inclusion and disability rights and feel very fortunate for having the opportunity to make a real difference and share the journeys of many disabled children and families through my charity Include Me TOO (inspired by my youngest son Callum).”

displayImages.caption:
Young achiever award - Tanya Datta, store manager at Marks & Spencer

“Whatever path you take there will always be ups and downs. Remain resilient and dream big. Nothing will ever go to plan. Always stay humble, always act with integrity. Inspire and take people with you on the journey.” Photograph: PR
displayImages.altText: Tanya Datta
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Young achiever award - Tanya Datta, store manager at Marks & Spencer

“Whatever path you take there will always be ups and downs. Remain resilient and dream big. Nothing will ever go to plan. Always stay humble, always act with integrity. Inspire and take people with you on the journey.”

cards.title: Shock and orca / Paddleboarder's close encounter with a whale
cards.rawTitle: Paddleboarder's close encounter with a whale

item.title: New Zealand paddleboarder's shock and orca at close encounter
item.trailText: A New Zealand man films a close encounter with an orca while paddleboading
item.standFirst: A New Zealand man films a close encounter with an orca while paddleboading. Luke Reilly said he was a little nervous but continued filming the killer whale which popped up off the coast of Whitianga on the Coromandel peninsula. "Someone said there's some orcas down the beach so I chucked the GoPro in my pocket because I had it surfing,' the 27-year-old told New Zealand's TV 3, adding he didn't think he'd get anything

stillImage.caption: An orca creeps up behind a New Zealand man's paddleboad Photograph: Luke Reilly/TV3 NZ Photograph: Luke Reilly/TV3 NZ
stillImage.cleanCaption: An orca creeps up behind a New Zealand man's paddleboad Photograph: Luke Reilly/TV3 NZ

cards.title: Toxteth then and now / Photographs of a bygone Liverpool

item.title: Toxteth then and now: photographs of a bygone Liverpool
item.trailText: When Tricia Porter moved to the notorious Liverpool 8 area in 1974, she was warned to carry a cosh – but emerged with a vivid portrait of a tight-knit community
item.standFirst:
When Tricia Porter moved to the notorious Liverpool 8 area in 1974, she was warned to carry a cosh – but emerged with a vivid portrait of a tight-knit community. Forty years on, she revisited the area

  • Tricia Porter: Liverpool Photographs 1972-74 is at Bluecoat, Liverpool, until July
item.byline: Words and photographs by Tricia Porter
item.body:
Some 40 years ago, in 1974, when I was a twentysomething from London, I made the move up north to Liverpool 8, an area of the city that was notorious for its poverty, planning blight and vandalism.

My future husband, David, was living there as a student. He was very concerned that, despite all that was being written and photographed about the area, where tight-knit communities were being pulled apart by redevelopment, its people were being forgotten.

Who were they? As a young photographer, I set out with David to find them, to tell their story in words and pictures as they went about their daily lives.

We started at the Bedford Stores, which had been recently relocated across the road to the new Myrtle Street shopping parade. Mr and Mrs Boswick and their staff told of former days when the Bedford Stores was a high-class grocer’s serving the wealthy in the area. They wanted to keep some of the ambience of the store in its new “supermarket-type” venue. We built up our contacts from there.

The resulting Bedford Street exhibition was shown at the Liverpool Academy of Arts, and later the Half Moon Gallery in London. The project gained Arts Council support, and I went on to create a follow-up exhibition, Some Liverpool Kids, which was also shown at the Academy a couple of years later.

On the other side of Upper Parliament Street, the Council had built housing for those who had been displaced by the redevelopment. I photographed the children there, playing outside, running errands and just hanging out, and was eventually welcomed into some of their homes.

Invites to schools and clubs followed, enabling me to gradually build up the story. I had been advised to carry a cosh with me, but I ignored the warning and never felt the need for one.

On the weekend that the photographs were shown again, this time as part of Look/15, Liverpool’s international photography festival at the Bluecoat, I returned with some of those who featured in the original pictures – Kevin Davies, Lizzie Hodson and her sister Jacquie, as well as some other family members. The area has since been known as Toxteth, following the riots of the 1980s.

Lizzie and Jacquie still live in the area, but their childhood homes – some of Liverpool 8’s larger houses – have been refurbished. New houses have replaced the tower blocks and smaller houses. The former Windsor Street school building is now a community centre, and the new school next door boasts of its high Ofsted rating.

Related: The street that might win the Turner prize: how Assemble are transforming Toxteth

Over near Falkner Street, what were once shops are now bistros. The area has a sense of gentrification, but half of the Myrtle Street shopping parade has gone – including the Bedford Stores – and a tower block is being built in its place. Redevelopment is continuing in Sugnall Street, but the Belvedere pub is still going strong. A lady I met at the exhibition told me she still lives in Percy Street. “At the time of the riots it was frightening,” she said. “The noise ... and I had a baby then.” But it was her home and she didn’t move away.

On our visit back to Liverpool 8, we were joined by Ann, whose brother and cousin were in the street football team picture. She reckons their homes will eventually be replaced with student accommodation, and that they will have to move further out of the city. The area, she says, is “too prime a spot, so near to the city centre”. Four decades on, there may still be a sense of fragility in Liverpool 8, but its residents remain as strong as ever, hanging on to their heritage and living their lives in the place they have always called home.

  • Tricia Porter: Liverpool Photographs 1972-74 is at Bluecoat, Liverpool, until July
  • See more photographs by Tricia Porter here

cards.title: No Borders protesters perform die-in at London St Pancras - video
cards.rawTitle: No Borders protesters perform die-in at London St Pancras

item.title: No Borders protesters perform die-in at London St Pancras
item.trailText: No Borders migrant solidarity protesters perform a bodybag die-in at the exit gates of the Eurostar in London St Pancras station on Tuesday evening, to highlight the deaths of 20,000 refugees
item.standFirst: No Borders migrant solidarity protesters perform a bodybag die-in at the exit gates of the Eurostar in London St Pancras station on Tuesday evening, to highlight the deaths of 20,000 refugees. The protest was called on the 10th anniversary of the Frontex agency being created to protect and manage the borders of the European Union. While funding for Frontex has increased to €118m (£84m) in 2011, search and rescue in the Mediterranean has seen a dramatic drop in funding, the result has been around 3,000 people losing their lives 2015 so far

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for No Borders protestors perform die-in at London St Pancras - video Photograph: guardian.co.uk
